$ETH  They gave us a pump and immediately dumped it. Could've been prepared. Let's take a look.  How could one have traded this manipulation? In this situation, there are three types of people: 1.  Went all-in on long positions; 2.  Analyzed the situation and went short (not all-in); 3.  Slept peacefully.  By a fortunate coincidence, I didn't have top-50 coins connected to my pump/dump monitor at that moment, so only liquidation alerts were active. Yet, even with that, you could have calmly caught a move.  I received an alert for a 4.5M$ volume of short position liquidation (wow, I was genuinely shocked). I open the chart and see the market is being pumped ‚Äì interesting. I quickly glance at the indicators to see what they're telling me: I see a distribution pattern, check the volumes, look at CVD and OI, and decide to wait a bit (in such volatile moves, it's better to catch your breath).  I continue watching the indicators: CVD is rising while OI is falling (shorts are being opened). I remember that 4.5M$ short liquidation alert and decide to open a short position with a stop-loss. Why? Because the long/short ratio delta shows no sign of long dominance. The big players are shorting ‚Äì it's time to ride with them. Then of course were long liquidation.     P.S. For those asking about data sources: I track such anomalies using specialized monitoring tools. If you're interested in the technical side, the names of the bots I use for this are in my CMC profile description. This isn't an ad, just full transparency about my process.

Not every scan produces a trade.
And that is exactly what a disciplined strategy should tell you.

Today‚Äôs prompt looked for a very specific setup.
It did not find one.

Here‚Äôs why that matters. 
Prompt:

Fetch BTC and ETH prices with volume profile showing high volume nodes (support zones) on daily chart. Identify which asset is currently testing a major volume node from below. Provide long setup: entry at volume node test, TP at next volume node above (+3-5%), stop loss below volume node (-2%), allocate 4-5% portfolio if volume confirms support.
This type of analysis is a volume node test strategy.

It looks for moments where price reclaims areas of heavy historical trading.
Not momentum chasing.
Not blind dip buying.
What is this strategy checking?

‚Ä¢ High-volume nodes are price levels where a lot of trading happened.
‚Ä¢ These zones often act as strong support or resistance.
‚Ä¢ A test from below means price is trying to regain acceptance.
‚Ä¢ Volume confirmation shows buyers are defending the level.

No test. No confirmation. No trade.
Current reality check

Neither BTC nor ETH is testing a major volume node from below.

Both are still trading above their key daily pivot zones.

That already disqualifies the ideal setup.
ETH status (closer, but not there yet)

ETH price: $2,855
Key volume node (pivot): $2,845.64
S1 support: $2,833.05

Volume is up 31 percent, but price is falling.
That suggests distribution, not accumulation.

ETH would need to dip into support and hold with volume to qualify.
BTC status

BTC price: $87,368
Key volume node (pivot): $86,898.78
S1 support: $86,357.76

BTC is mid-range, RSI neutral, no clear interaction with a high-volume node.

No edge here either.
Important context

Both BTC and ETH are below their 21-day EMAs.
That signals bearish momentum.

In this environment, volume spikes on red candles are a warning, not a green light.
Strategy conclusion

This is a wait, not a trade.

The strategy will only act if:
‚Ä¢ price tests a volume node from below
‚Ä¢ volume confirms defense
‚Ä¢ structure improves

Until then, capital stays idle.
Bottom line:

Good strategies say ‚Äúno‚Äù more often than ‚Äúbuy‚Äù.
That is how risk is controlled.
